Use your hardware sensors at these optimal times to verify local temperature, humidity, and light pollution for perfect observation conditions!
Cloud coverage is the #1 factor for successful astronomy sessions. Planning ahead helps you choose the best nights for observation, ensuring clear skies and minimal light interference from clouds.
Moon phase affects deep-sky observation. Full moon creates light pollution, while new moon provides the darkest skies for viewing galaxies and nebulae.
Best meteor shower of the year! Peak viewing with up to 120 meteors per hour.

Celestial events like meteor showers, eclipses, and planet alignments are rare opportunities for spectacular observations and photography. Planning ahead ensures you don't miss these amazing cosmic shows!
Cloud cover affects visibility in astrophotography. Less cloud cover means clearer skies.
Telescope lens thickness impacts light-gathering ability, affecting astrophotography clarity.
Temperature and humidity affect air stability and lens fogging, crucial for clear telescopic observations.
Ambient light levels impact visibility of celestial objects and determine optimal exposure settings for astrophotography.
Score considers cloud cover, telescope specs, temperature, humidity and light pollution. Each parameter is rated 1-4 (worst-best), converted to 10-point scale and averaged.
